Read our thoughts here!

The winners of Wave 3 won't just manage data efficiently. They'll extract meaningful insights from complexity, automate away human toil, and align their success with their customers' outcomes. 

Who will lead this next wave of innovation?

The challenges are clear: data overload, spiraling costs, human bottlenecks, and persistent downtime. 

With global cloud spending projected to exceed $1 trillion by 2024, solving these issues represents an enormous opportunity. The observability sector is primed for explosive… https://t.co/MdR0d2CnND

Kinda wild but a shift from volume-based to outcome-based pricing could realign the entire industry's incentives. 

Imagine paying for observability based on accurately identified root causes or reduced MTTR, not data volume.

This brings us to Wave 3. The next frontier isn't just about managing data – it's about extracting actionable intelligence and radically reducing human effort. AI and ML will be crucial, enabling natural language interfaces, automated incident response, and predictive… https://t.co/SAsyqSdHjq

The elephant in the room? Human labor. While we've obsessed over data and tools, we've overlooked the growing army of humans required to make sense of it all. SREs, commanding six-figure salaries, spend up to 30% of their time just triaging alerts. MTTR for critical incidents… https://t.co/ol8wQfZ3ee

Despite Wave 2 innovations, challenges persist. High-cardinality data and massive log volumes pushed even advanced databases to their limits. As cloud spend accelerated, observability costs began to outpace value delivered. The haystack grew faster than our ability to find the… https://t.co/nvVPNMoFzS

Enter Wave 2. Companies like Honeycomb, Grafana Labs, and Cribl tackled data complexity, tool sprawl, and costs. Cribl's meteoric rise to $100M ARR in under 5 years underscored the urgency. These solutions were necessary because Wave 1's volume-based pricing inadvertently… https://t.co/ajItnmL60f

Cloud adoption introduced unprecedented complexity. Microservices, containers, and Kubernetes led to a data explosion. A paradox emerged: more data, less insight. Organizations built data lakes just to navigate their observability data.

The evolution of observability is a case study in solving problems while inadvertently creating new ones. Early pioneers like Splunk and AppDynamics made opaque systems transparent. Their success was clear: Splunk's 2012 IPO valued it north of 1B+
There is profound wisdom in recognizing when your current inspiration fades
rap > EDM

Challenges remain: real-time processing, data privacy, handling time series data, and true causal reasoning. But innovations in multimodality and multi-agent systems show promise. Near-term, expect creative workarounds from builders.

Enter LLMs. They offer unified data understanding, correlating logs, metrics, and traces. They bring zero-shot learning, natural language interfaces, and context-aware analysis. Potential for automated root cause analysis could slash MTTR by an order of magnitude.

Previous "smart" observability attempts have fallen short. Supervised learning lacks labeled data for rare failures. Feature engineering across diverse sources is Herculean. Black-box models don't gain DevOps trust. And drift in continuous deployment is a nightmare.

Current challenges: Data volume/velocity, heterogeneous formats, lack of unified models, query complexity, high-cardinality issues, and alert correlation. 

Result? Engineers spend 30% of time triaging alerts, with MTTR for critical incidents averaging 4-5 hours sometimes

The observability market is fragmented, with leaders like Datadog and Splunk rarely capturing >20% market share. Why? Because observability has been treated as a big data problem, not an intelligence problem. 

The challenge isn't collecting data—it's making sense of it.

Goodbye AIOps: welcome AgentSREs—the next $100B opportunity

"AIOps" is just another buzzword that fails to capture the true potential of AI in IT ops and observability. 

We're on the cusp of a fundamental shift in how organizations monitor, debug, and optimize complex software… https://t.co/a51v3iOAJC

We are at a unique time in history. Every layer in the AI stack is improving exponentially, with no signs of a slowdown in sight. 

As a result, many founders feel that they are building on quicksand. On the flip side, this flywheel also presents a generational opportunity.… https://t.co/oGqELvxckv

For that reason, multi-context handling is the next frontier. Current AI struggles with tasks that require switching between multiple contexts or using a variety of tools. Solving this challenge could lead to AI assistants capable of handling complex, multi-step tasks that mirror… https://t.co/VFHGM9nGd1
So wheres the value? the real economic impact of AI will come from models that can reliably handle 30-45 minute complex tasks, not just quick interactions.

For founders, it's more about combining models with specialized tools, not just improving the models themselves. 

It's about creating smarter systems, not just smarter models.

To address this, improving LLM reasoning and planning capabilities may offer more immediate value than pushing multimodal boundaries. For this reason, we see the LLM providers investing more in the former. (applications in complex decision-making)

However, specialization has its limits. Grounding LLMs in the real world remains a significant challenge. Current systems rely too heavily on language priors, limiting their ability in tasks requiring real-world interaction.
Speaking of specificity, specialized open-source models could be as impactful as general closed-source models. This trend may lead to more efficient, accurate solutions for specific domains.

This inertia is driving innovation in other areas. Task-specific model routing, like mixture-of-experts systems, could be more efficient than monolithic models. This mimics how we don't use all parts of our brain for every task.

Transformer architecture inertia is significant. But we are seeing a lot of incremental improvements around pushing the bounds of scaling them across latency, cost, modalities, data, etc. and starting to see investment in different model architectures (which are exciting)

Globally Distributed Training Setting

We train a billion parameter scale model across three countries.

Scaling DiLoCo to Billion Parameter Models

The original DiLoCo work only experimented with model sizes of up to 400 million parameters. We scale the method to a 1.1 billion parameter model.

While we demonstrate that DiLoCo works at the billion-parameter scale, we believe… https://t.co/klkVLJ1IyL https://t.co/ZILrNh46kp

We should talk about this more, it's not an often-cited reason developers start using Convex today (Types! Reactive subscriptions! Consistent client-side views! Transactions with OCC in TypeScript!) but it core to the  infrastructure DNA of the company and vision for reliability.
Convex makes the cost of your queries visible and doesn't use primitives for things that aren't fast. The query plan is your code, no need to EXPLAIN.

With SQL you write a join (or 4) and the query optimizer decides how to implement it. This is convenient and but opaque and inconsistent, so you ask the DB to EXPLAIN and grumble when this query plan changes.
chatting with @stevekrouse this morning about how the @convex_dev query language is TypeScript the fact that it *doesn't have a primitive for joins* came up. This is surprising!

...the first answer I get says that LMs require a lot of training data, while the second answer (for the identical prompt) says that data sparsity and training on small datasets is the main challenge facing LMs right now.

I also found that sometimes the model's responses would directly contradict each other for the same prompt. 

For example, if I ask "What are the primary weaknesses of large language models?"

P: What weighs more, a kilogram of steel or a kilogram of feathers? 

R: A kilogram of steel.

P: Are you sure? Why?

R: A kilogram is a unit of measurement for weight, not for volume.
Pretty good! However, I was able to fool it with a fun "riddle"...

P: Yesterday I dropped my clothes off at the dry cleaner’s and I have yet to pick them up. Where are my clothes?

R: If you dropped your clothes off at the dry cleaner's and you have yet to pick them up, they are probably still at the dry cleaner's.

P: ...juice into it. It looks okay. You try sniffing it, but you have a bad cold, so you can’t smell anything. You are very thirsty. So you decide 

R: to give it a try. The grape juice doesn't really change the flavor of the cranberry juice too much, so it's still pretty good.

Now, even tho its clear that it saves time by parking far...

We’ll still be looking for a spot close to the store entrance cuz that’s what the gf wants lol.

Results:
Close Spot Total Time Over 6 Months: 104 minutes.
Far Spot Total Time Over 6 Months (with adjusted walk time): 96 minutes. https://t.co/LkRDQ8Ukh0

Far Spot Strategy:
Each Trip: 0 minutes finding + 4 minutes walking = 4 minutes per trip.
Total for 24 trips: 4 min per trip×24 trips=96 min. https://t.co/9z5IBBJTHY

Data Analysis:
Close Spot Strategy:
- Normal Trips (2 out of 3): 1 minute finding + 2 minutes walking = 3 minutes per trip.
- Adjusted Trip (1 out of 3): 5 minutes finding + 2 minutes walking = 7 minutes for this trip.
Every 3 trips: 6 min for 2 trips + 7 min for 1 trip=13 min
-… https://t.co/XK6FoUYyMJ

Far Spot Strategy:
No time spent finding a spot.
2 minutes walk each way (4 minutes walking total). https://t.co/6BmQLNp4FO

Close Spot Strategy:

Normal condition: 1 minute to find a spot, 1 minute walk each way (2 minutes walking total).

Sometimes it takes a while to find a spot. So, for every 2-3 trips: 5 minutes to find a spot due to increased competition, 1 minute walk each way. https://t.co/P2eceMJLfm

Assumptions
(I actually timed these assumptions)
- Grocery Shopping Frequency: 24 trips over 6 months.
-  2 Strategies: Close Spot Strategy and Far Spot Strategy https://t.co/s7HUnfNZ0S

The EU aims to finalize the AI ACT by the end of the year. This legislation could set a precedent for AI regulation worldwide, balancing the benefits of AI with the need to protect individual rights and freedoms.

The tech industry's reactions to the proposed EU legislation on AI use are mixed. Some call for legislation, others criticize it as too prescriptive and potentially hindering innovation. The final shape of the legislation is currently under discussion. https://t.co/c7J9DzMWWy
Technologies like Chat GPT have influenced discussions around the legislation, with lawmakers considering adding new elements to prevent the creation of illegal content.

The creation of illegal content by AI is also a concern. The AI ACT aims to prevent this by requiring companies to publish summaries of copyrighted data used to train AI models, ensuring the output doesn't infringe on copyright laws. https://t.co/AkzaI2jMmr

Predictive policing is another high-risk application. It involves using AI to predict potential criminal activity based on data like criminal histories and real-time biometric surveillance.

https://t.co/gUyghLtqeA

One high-risk application is the use of facial recognition tools. While useful, they can infringe on privacy rights if not properly regulated. The AI ACT aims to put guardrails around such applications to ensure ethical use. https://t.co/wEr5vaeUl1

The EU Parliament is pushing forward the AI ACT. 

The goal? To establish guidelines around the development and use of AI, particularly for high-risk applications.

Handshake. Worth $3.5 billion. Raised seed in 2015

It built a job site for college kids to find their first job

I can only imagine how many people wrote them off early on

Some examples:
- Airbnb was selling spare bedrooms for a night in 2009
- Coinbase was building a crypto exchange in 2012
- Etsy was enabling hobbyists to sell crafts in 2005
- Tesla was building a high-end electric car in 2004

it was easy to call these ideas niche at the time

great startups often sound like shit businesses

10/
Look, haters gonna hate. I’m one guy that moved here, fell in love with it, & sharing why. I think life is about being around kind people, enjoying the little moments of life, & having the opportunity to pursue the things that make you most passionate. Find that place for you

9/
Go visit Detroit and see the artists & dreamers rebuilding that city. Swing by a small town & I guarantee you will be met with kindness. The point is simplicity empowers clarity, to see & be who you want to be in this life. Like anything, beauty is in the eye of the beholder

8/
That simplicity doesn’t stop the dreamers & builders. Chicago didn’t have mountains, so they built skyscrapers. They needed clean drinking water from the lake, so they reversed the river. It’s no surprise the most optimistic US president in the last 60 years came from Chicago

7/
That manifests itself in many ways. It’s Chicago in the summertime. It’s boating on a lake in Wisconsin or Minnesota. It’s sitting on a beach in Michigan. It’s watching a baseball game on a summer night at Wrigley Field. It’s watching the snow fall from your window in February

6/
The by-product of all that is you learn to find satisfaction where you are. You learn to be kind to your neighbor. You learn to define your own dreams vs let the world define it for you. The Midwest’s simplicity is its beauty. In a world of chaos, sometimes less is more

5/
You see, there are no mountains to run to. You don’t move or stay here for the sunny skies or warm weather (altho summer is incredible). Most people aren’t moving here to chase something. Which I realize sounds incredibly unappealing, but bear with me

4/
I think many places & cultures are ultimately products of their geography, directly or indirectly. Well, the Midwest…is a lot of flat farmable land. On the surface, not super appealing to most. But if you look closely, you start to realize the beautiful by-product that drives

3/
About 8 years ago I moved here from NYC. I honestly thought it was a stopover for a few years while I made myself west to California. Over time, though, I fell in love with the city & the region…but not for the reasons I first mentioned

2/
At first, my love was driven by the vibrancy of the city, the cultural pockets & diversity, the architecture, the mix of old & new. As you learn about the city’s history, you realize this has long been a haven for dreamers & builders. Chicago was built from the swamp & the ash

1/

Relatedly, some cool work by @kellychiuyy @sharma_ashish_2 where they found LLMs typically don’t ask enough questions on experiences and jump too quickly to problem-solving (though better prompts can nudge them in the right direction). Check it out: https://t.co/MjoyiLq9fN https://t.co/SzQWmh2OlW

Because talk therapy is so reliant on careful word choice, prompts disproportionately matter for applications of LLMs to counseling/therapy. I’m very curious about what a “great” prompt would be + the relative possible improvement

Using web agents for fuzzy E2E tests, you could test whether software agents correctly implement web dev features. With enough cases, could be an interesting way to benchmark AI’s full stack web dev skills (aka, am I cooked as a product engineer)

Dropped another blog post with @chenxcynthia! We broke down Gemini's double-check response feature. TLDR, we think it's an innovative approach to verifying LLM outputs but simpler methods are more effective. Check it out here: https://t.co/9b9xpIMKDx https://t.co/KbFdsoEWC6
Full paper here: https://t.co/O9QY3zHGh4

If software agents wrongly think they resolve bugs 80% of the time, automated test generation becomes really important! Cool work by @nielstron @mnmueller @jingxuan_he who adapted SWE-bench to focus on this but found agents could only write the relevant tests for 11.1% of issues

Ex: for astropy-13572, Claude keeps failing to open the right file, but for astropy-13404, GPT4 gets caught up trying to understand context and hits a cost limit. Couldn't find real patterns between failures besides that SWE-agent/Claude has trouble setting up Django environments

Holding scaffolding constant, comparing SWE-agent when run on GPT4 vs Claude 3 Opus, GPT4 performed better with 73 extra tasks solved. However, GPT4 technically solved 147 that Claude could not (and Claude did 71 that GPT couldn’t).

In fact, you can run all of the agents on SWE-bench and get to 32%. So software agents with higher accuracy are not Pareto improvements over those with lower accuracy — scaffolding and model choice can present meaningful tradeoffs

State of the art on SWE-bench is 19% but that doesn’t reflect the percentage of open source issues “solvable” by AI. Ex: even though the top two software agents (@FactoryAI @AutoCodeRover) both solve ~435 tasks, lack of overlap means running both gets you to 583 (25% accuracy) 1/

I imagine even if agents were more reliable but less capable (ex: 90% of PRs were robust but only submitted for 15% of tasks), we might see more takeoff — makes me wonder how to get agents to be unsure rather than confidently wrong + how big of a problem this is in practice

Reliability as a big bottleneck for software agents? The state-of-the-art agent solves 19% of SWE-bench but submits patches for almost all tasks, so 80% of its PRs don’t fly. Analyzed the agent logs and ~1/3 of failed submissions regress on previously working tests https://t.co/fzqM21UsEz

Tech report here (section 5.1) if you want to read more. Note they don't do much analysis but do cite the original papers! https://t.co/EDfrcQhsAQ

(also, I had to use a plot digitizer to pull numbers off the graphs which is why all the percentages are rough estimates)

Another explored changing the order of answer choices (ex: swapping the choice at D with the one at C), and the 405B model can see (roughly) a full percentage point change depending on the ordering

Note the reported numbers are that gpt4o is 88.7% and 405B is 88.6% https://t.co/tsLcbk6Egz

One of the four robustness experiments explored changing the labels on MMLU, and when they did ABCD -> $&#@, the 405B model drops from ~84% to ~64%! In fact, 70B actually outperforms the 405B (at ~69% accuracy)

For reference, gpt3.5 turbo gets 69.8% on standard MMLU (ABCD) https://t.co/cR1WD11Vy3

Note, they only report on the pretrained model so it doesn't include any of the finetuning that really gets the 3.1 evals to be competitive with the other frontier models. For example, MATH benchmark performance improved from 53.8% (~gpt4 in Nov 2023) to 73.8% (~claude 3.5)

Found the evals section of the Llama 3.1 technical report really interesting! They (briefly) explore how robust Llama 3.1 is to benchmark design decisions, and it's a good reminder to not blindly trust metrics (ex: 70B model can beat 405B!). More details below 🧵

When we talked to Sara, she told us about the history of the feature — how it was first an internal tool useful for demos and how they're always drawing inspiration from human coworker interactions. Check out our full post at https://t.co/ekG9TtWEs0

We're bullish on the video player because it's an observability tool that signals trust in the best way — see for yourself. But, consider Devin like an intern and you don't want to step through every action, seeing the final PR is enough!

at the moment, my strategy going forward is simple: 
- crank up the temperature 
- increase the cap of considered samples
and see what happens

so how to restrict the search space?
- artificially cap the number of children per node (current approach)
- use properties of PL to restrict allowed tokens (interesting but a pain to do)
- ...?
sentences on the other hand are not finite, and imposing finiteness on them in this fashion is probably the root cause of the problem

in classic alphazero, you choose your next action based on the output of your policy network. it's conducted over a finite action space. tokens are nice because they are also a finite action space (if large in count).
if i give the model three samples at the root level, and it picks three variations of "for i in range..." then the search space ends up collapsing.

why token level -> sentence level? 
- i couldn't get a reward model to give any meaningful signal on singular tokens but its pretty good at evaluating a few sentences at a time
- one token at a time is wildly inefficient and i need to speed this up for practicality

i'd figured i needed to swap out tokens -> sentences for mcts codegen to move to full alphazero (reasons below) but sentence generation diversity is a whole lot lower and it's holding back the search... a 🧵

discoveries
- for large enough k (but only large enough k) MCTS inference will outperform randomly sampling
- on average, if random sampling took 10 tries to get the right answer, MCTS would only need 6.77 attempts

over enough attempts, MCTS searches soln space more efficiently

✨ extremely fun side project discovery today: getting LLM + MCTS working! ✨

here's the setup:
- take humaneval and llama
- use MCTS-assisted inference decoding (with humenval pass/fail as reward) with k rollouts / question
- compare it to sampling the model for pass@k scores
Folks working on LLM + MCTS! Have there been instances of MCTS outperforming random search at equivalent compute? My attempts to reproduce this for coding haven't been gainful yet

For LLM + MCTS approaches, doesn't it make sense to compare pass@k with k rollouts of MCTS?

This way, you give the model k shots at target in both cases, and the hope is that MCTS uses the reward signal to balance exploration / exploitation better

Conclusion — There's a DIRE need for flexible, plug and play loyalty tools that can accommodate the dynamic nature of current customer engagement / community experience. If you want your loyalty program to be scalable, interactive and build a partner program, DM me for the guide!

When designing a new program keep in mind that Omni-channel interaction, Reward Redemption via partner programs and Exclusive Access/Experiences where Customers can showcase their status were voted as the top benefits.

Building a Reward Partner program is more critical then ever. Yet, existing programs often offer only 3-6 fixed benefits, and only at sales point. 1 in 3 customers churn after redeeming all the fixed benefits. And, Brands see existing tools as sunk cost...

Why are loyalty programs not targeting the top 10%?
With more choices than ever, today’s customers demand more… 80% customers stated they will stay in a brand if their reward has utility – either frequency of usage or other redemption areas. So what should you do as a brand? 🤔

~80% of a brand’s revenue typically comes from just 10% of its customer base. Yet, 2/3 brands still spend $$$ on ads and are seeing 2x more costs in acquisition with lower retention (customer acquisition costs are 60% higher than before!)
So we dug deeper...

Over the past 2 years, we have talked to 300+ brands (10440+ minutes spent) on their brand loyalty and retention needs so you didn’t have to. Here’s what we found that you NEED to know if you are managing a brand…
One of the largest markets with little innovation.. how did we sleep on this for decades?

It surprises me every day ( and excites me) that existing loyalty providers for enterprise usually look for $200k upfront costs and "intentionally" do not build a CRM or analytics tool for customers so that they need the provider again whenever the program needs a change...

Traditional providers stifle program growth and flexibility, forcing brands to rely heavily on agencies for even minor changes –   due to the absence of integrations and composable components or rewards by existing providers.

Did you know...Most loyalty Programs often offer only 3-6 fixed benefits, and only at sales points.  

With the Rise of CAC, customers are demanding more... yet loyalty benefits are only changeable with significant engineering intervention within current systems.

What sets @KITH apart? retroactive rewards: past actions earn points towards exclusive perks like early access & events. It's a loyalty revolution valuing each engagement. 🌟

If you have any questions about cold outreach, drop them in the comments below! Also, if you liked this thread, please retweet so your friends can see it too 😃

A Numbers Game

Even with a great intro message, cold outreach is a numbers game. To be successful, you’ll have to get used to being rejected, constantly. It just takes 1 response to radically change your life.

Why this works?

Essentially, people are busy. They want to be sold on why they should offer up 30 minutes of their day to chat. A generic message doesn't get the job done, because they have no idea why they should be speaking with you.

The Right Intro Message

- Is super specific and lets them know your similarities (college, career, etc.)
- Specifies what the purpose of chatting is, whether it's to establish a partnership, get feedback on your idea, or open the door to a new friendship

The Wrong Intro Message

The most important part of cold outreach is your intro message. A generic intro message where the call to action is “would you be open to chatting?” with very little outside context will almost never get a response. This is what 99% of people are doing.

At its core, cold outreach is reaching out to someone who you have no connection with and trying to form a relationship with them. 

This can be done through email, LinkedIn, Twitter, and even in-person. Although it sounds simple, most people are doing it wrong.

At the age of 22, cold outreach has allowed me to build a 6-figure recruiting agency, have 1-on-1 chats with amazing founders and investors, host AI events for over 200 people, and make tons of new friends.

Introducing the Cold Outreach technique 👇 https://t.co/YhRXEt3h76

3. Handing out too many "equity snacks" to advisors, or senior hires 🍟
It's easy to dole out equity in the early days when you can't pay very much, but painful if it amounts to something down the line. Pick advisors that equate to sales or good hires, not just fancy resumes.

2. Overloading on cofounders 👨‍👨‍👦‍👦

The chances that one of your cofounders leaves is incredibly high within the first couple of years. Two cofounders is awesome. Three is great if there are complementary skills. Four is usually too many.

You're raising VC to be a huge company. Most companies are not huge, don't need to be, and can own a niche profitably. There are countless examples of companies that bootstrap or use debt and create a massive opportunity.

In addition to these classes I'm taking, my co-founder is taking Natural Language Processing (NLP) and Applied Machine Learning to complement my skillsets.

Web Development (COMS 3102)
- duh

Applied Computing - Research and Industry Perspectives (BC 3997)
- Human Computer Interaction research basically documenting every step of building @scraftai 
- Final project: Talk to users, build, and launch

Introduction to Databases (COMS 4111)
- entity-relationship modeling, logical design of relational databases, query processing, physical database tuning, transaction processing, security
- Final project: Build a backend application with friends!

User interface and Design (COMS 4117)
- How to design a good user interface consistent to Usability Heuristics
- How to conduct usability tests with user interviews
- Final project: Design a frontend application with friends
